subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: A couple of questions from a newbie
msgSnippet: ... QS is *not* capable of representing every accent of English unless more than one sound is represented by the same letter.  For example, can = be able
messageBody:
moira_ob scripsit:

> The whole point of Quikscript
> is that it is capable of reflecting local ways of speaking - be it
> American, Australian, Standard English or whatever. It is a phonetic
> alphabet and that assumes that it will be written as it is spoken.

QS is *not* capable of representing every accent of English unless
more than one sound is represented by the same letter. For example,
"can" = "be able" does not sound the same in New York City as "can" =
"metal container", but QS has no way to represent the difference.
Still less is QS able to represent every accent of English simultaneously,
as the IPA can do, unless more than one sound is represented by the
same letter across accents. For example, the vowel of "goat" is not
the same in North American accents as it is in RP, but QS has no way
to represent the difference. The same is true of the vowel of "mouth"
as pronounced in Australia and in the Northern Hemisphere, but again
QS can't tell the difference.

To make things worse, writing in QS exactly as we speak will cause severe
problems with intelligibility across accent boundaries. If Alice from
London writes <Fife, Eat, Fife>, North Americans will not recognize this
as "thief". If Bob from Philadelphia writes <Deed, Ah, Loll>, people
from outside North America will not recognize this as "doll". If Charlie
from Edinburgh writes <Tut, Ed, Roar, Mime>, only people from Scotland
and Ireland and those who know traditional orthography will recognize
this as "term". If David from New Zealand writes <Sis, Ado, Ax>, only
his countrymen will recognize this as "six"; all other anglophones will
take it to be "sucks". ("Australia sux, New Zealand nil.") Likewise,
Eve from California will bewilder most of us with her <Kick, Eat,
Inkling>, as the rest of us say <Kick, If, Inkling> for "king".

When Frank, a policeman from Chicago, writes that he searched every <Bob,
Loll, Ash, Kick> for guns, the rest of us may think this is racial
profiling, but Frank merely meant that he searched every "block".
Greta from Newcastle-on-Tyne may write <Kick, Wool, Deed>, and people
outside the North of England will think she is writing "could" rather than
"cud". When Henry from Cardiff, Princess Imogen of Britain, James from
Melbourne, and Kayla from Indianapolis write <Deed, If, Win-win>, <Deed,
Yo-yo, Ooze>, <Judge, Ooze>, and <Deed, Ooze> respectively, it will take
them some work to figure out that all these spellings represent the word
"dew". I could go on for a *very* long time.

--
Principles. You can't say A is John Cowan <cowan@...>
made of B or vice versa. All mass http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
is interaction. --Richard Feynman
